Consent: Consent Form for IRB-FY2021-5770 Welcome and thank you for participating    You have been invited to take part in a research study about economic and political issues in the United Kingdom. This study is conducted by researchers at New York University (Pablo Querubin and David Stasavage, Politics Department, Graduate School of Arts and Science), Yale University (Kenneth Scheve, Department of Political Science, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences) and the University of Geneva (Mariana Alvarado, Department of Political Science).       If you agree to be in this study, you will be asked to do the following:     1. Complete a questionnaire to provide basic information on yourself and provide information on your position on political issues such as partisanship.      2. Answer questions on selected issues, mostly regarding taxation.     Participation in this study will take about 8 minutes.     There are no known risks associated with your participation in this research beyond those of everyday life. Although you will receive no direct benefits, this research may help the researchers understand what people think about important public policy questions in the United Kingdom.     You will be compensated for completing the survey.     Confidentiality of your research records will be strictly maintained by assigning code numbers to each participant so the data is never directly linked to individual identities. Aggregated responses will only be used for scientific purposes.     Participation in this study is voluntary. You may refuse to participate or withdraw at any time without penalty, by closing the browser window. Furthermore, you have the right to skip or not answer any questions you prefer not to answer. However, you will not be paid unless you finish the survey questionnaire.     If there is anything about the study or your participation that is unclear or that you do not understand, if you have questions or wish to report a research-related problem, you may contact Pablo Querubin at +1 (212) 998 8500, pablo.querubin@nyu.edu, 19 W. 4th Street New York, NY 10012.     For questions about your rights as a research participant, you may contact the University Committee on Activities Involving Human Subjects (NYU IRB), New York University, 665 Broadway, Suite 804, New York, NY 10012, at (212) 998-4808 or ask.humansubjects@nyu.edu. If you contact the NYU IRB, please refer to the number of this study: IRB-FY2021-5770.     Please print a copy of this consent document to keep.    Select one of the following options to continue. If you choose not to participate, the survey will end immediately.

Q17: The Covid-19 pandemic had a disproportionate impact on different groups of people. Those with lower incomes were particularly affected, both in terms of contracting the virus and experiencing unemployment. In England, adults living in the poorest areas were almost four times more likely to die from Covid-19 compared to those in the wealthiest areas. Additionally, low-wage workers were three times as likely to face job disruptions compared to high-wage workers.  At the same time, the pandemic led to a further increase in the wealth of the already wealthy. The top 10% of households saw their wealth grow by an average of £50,000, and UK billionaires collectively gained £54 billion in the first year of the pandemic alone.  Certain government policies contributed to this unequal distribution of burdens. Although strict lockdowns and business closures were necessary to control the spread of the virus, they had a particularly negative impact on lower-income workers who had fewer opportunities to work from home. Middle and high-income households, on the other hand, were better able to adapt to remote work, which protected them from both financial and health risks. Additionally, certain sectors such as information technology and online retailing saw significant profits, while industries like hospitality suffered immense losses.

Q17: The Covid-19 pandemic had a disproportionate impact on different groups of people. Low-income households faced higher rates of Covid infections and unemployment compared to wealthier areas. The risk of death from Covid-19 was significantly higher in England's poorest areas. Additionally, low-wage workers were more likely to experience job disruptions compared to high-wage workers. Meanwhile, the wealthiest individuals and households saw their wealth increase during the pandemic, with the top 10% of households gaining an average of £50,000 and UK billionaires increasing their wealth by £54 billion in the first year alone. Government policies, such as strict lockdowns and business closures, exacerbated these inequalities. Lower-income workers, who had fewer opportunities to work from home, were particularly affected, while middle and high-income households were able to adapt to remote work, reducing their income and health risks. Certain sectors, like information technology and online retailing, experienced significant profits, while others, like hospitality, suffered substantial losses.
Q33_1: Government policies such as strict lockdowns and business closures, while necessary to curb the spread of the virus, disproportionately affected lower-income groups who have limited options for remote work or financial stability. These measures resulted in job losses and economic hardships for those who were already economically vulnerable.
Q33_2: The government's response in terms of financial support and assistance during the pandemic was not equally distributed. The availability and accessibility of aid programs may have favored higher-income individuals and businesses, further exacerbating the disparities. Insufficient support for low-income households and lack of targeted assistance could contribute to the unequal burden experienced during the pandemic.

Q17: The text discusses how the Covid-19 pandemic led to unequal impacts on various segments of society. It highlights that low-income households faced higher rates of Covid infections and job loss, leading to greater mortality and economic hardship. In contrast, wealthier individuals and certain industries experienced financial gains during the pandemic. Government policies, such as lockdowns, exacerbated these inequalities by disproportionately affecting lower-income workers and favoring those who could work remotely or were in profitable sectors.
Q33_1: Government-imposed measures, such as lockdowns and business closures, were necessary to control the spread of the virus. However, these measures had varying impacts on different socioeconomic groups. Lower-income individuals, often employed in industries like hospitality and retail, were more likely to lose their jobs due to these restrictions. Critics argue that the government's policies could have been more targeted and comprehensive, including providing adequate support for affected workers and businesses, to mitigate the unequal economic impact.
Q33_2: The pandemic exposed existing disparities in access to resources and healthcare. Lower-income individuals often have less access to quality healthcare, making them more vulnerable to Covid-19. Additionally, the ability to work remotely and continue earning income was a privilege largely available to those in higher-income brackets. Some argue that the government should have taken more proactive steps to address these disparities and ensure that essential resources and support were equitably distributed.
